verses.kjv: And it was told Joab, Behold, the king weepeth and mourneth for Absalom.
verses.ct: Someone reported to Joab, "The king is weeping and grieving over Absalom."

verses.kjv: And the victory that day was turned into mourning unto all the people: for the people heard say that day how the king was grieved for his son.
verses.ct: What should have been a day of celebration turned into mourning for the entire army, because everyone heard that the king was heartbroken over his son.

verses.kjv: And the people gat them by stealth that day into the city, as people being ashamed steal away when they flee in battle.
verses.ct: The troops slipped quietly into the city that day, sneaking in like soldiers ashamed of running from battle.

verses.kjv: But the king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice, O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!
verses.ct: The king covered his face and kept crying out loudly, "My son Absalom! Absalom, my son, my son!"

verses.kjv: And Joab came into the house to the king, and said, Thou hast shamed this day the faces of all thy servants, which this day have saved thy life, and the lives of thy sons and of thy daughters, and the lives of thy wives, and the lives of thy concubines;
verses.ct: Joab went into the house where the king was and said, "Today you have humiliated every one of your soldiers — the people who saved your life, the lives of your sons and daughters, and the lives of your wives and secondary wives.

verses.kjv: In that thou lovest thine enemies, and hatest thy friends. For thou hast declared this day, that thou regardest neither princes nor servants: for this day I perceive, that if Absalom had lived, and all we had died this day, then it had pleased thee well.
verses.ct: You act like you love those who hate you and hate those who love you. You've made it clear today that your commanders and soldiers mean nothing to you. I can see now that if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead, you would be perfectly happy.

verses.kjv: Now therefore arise, go forth, and speak comfortably unto thy servants: for I swear by the LORD, if thou go not forth, there will not tarry one with thee this night: and that will be worse unto thee than all the evil that befell thee from thy youth until now.
verses.ct: So get up, go outside, and encourage your troops. I swear by the LORD, if you don't go out, not a single soldier will stay with you tonight. That will be far worse for you than every disaster you've faced from your youth until now."

verses.kjv: Then the king arose, and sat in the gate. And they told unto all the people, saying, Behold, the king doth sit in the gate. And all the people came before the king: for Israel had fled every man to his tent.
verses.ct: So the king got up and took his seat at the city gate. When word spread to all the troops that the king was sitting at the gate, they all came and gathered in front of him. Meanwhile, the Israelites who had followed Absalom had scattered and gone home.

verses.kjv: And all the people were at strife throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, The king saved us out of the hand of our enemies, and he delivered us out of the hand of the Philistines; and now he is fled out of the land for Absalom.
verses.ct: Throughout all the tribes of Israel, people were arguing with each other, saying, "The king rescued us from our enemies and saved us from the Philistines, but now he has fled the country because of Absalom.

verses.kjv: And Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now therefore why speak ye not a word of bringing the king back?
verses.ct: And Absalom, the one we anointed to rule over us, has died in battle. So why isn't anyone talking about bringing the king back?"

verses.kjv: And king David sent to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, saying, Speak unto the elders of Judah, saying, Why are ye the last to bring the king back to his house? seeing the speech of all Israel is come to the king, even to his house.
verses.ct: King David sent a message to the priests Zadok and Abiathar: "Say to the elders of Judah, 'Why should you be the last ones to bring the king back to his palace? Word has already reached the king from all of Israel that they want him back.'

verses.kjv: Ye are my brethren, ye are my bones and my flesh: wherefore then are ye the last to bring back the king?
verses.ct: You are my relatives — my own flesh and blood. So why should you be the last to bring the king back?

verses.kjv: And say ye to Amasa, Art thou not of my bone, and of my flesh? God do so to me, and more also, if thou be not captain of the host before me continually in the room of Joab.
verses.ct: And tell Amasa, 'Aren't you my own flesh and blood? May God punish me severely if I don't make you the permanent commander of my army in place of Joab.'"

verses.kjv: And he bowed the heart of all the men of Judah, even as the heart of one man; so that they sent this word unto the king, Return thou, and all thy servants.
verses.ct: David won over the hearts of all the people of Judah so completely that they were united as one. They sent word to the king: "Come back, you and all your servants."

verses.kjv: So the king returned, and came to Jordan. And Judah came to Gilgal, to go to meet the king, to conduct the king over Jordan.
verses.ct: So the king started back and arrived at the Jordan River. The people of Judah had come to Gilgal to meet the king and escort him across the Jordan.

verses.kjv: And Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite, which was of Bahurim, hasted and came down with the men of Judah to meet king David.
verses.ct: Shimei son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried down with the men of Judah to meet King David.

verses.kjv: And there were a thousand men of Benjamin with him, and Ziba the servant of the house of Saul, and his fifteen sons and his twenty servants with him; and they went over Jordan before the king.
verses.ct: With him were 1,000 men from the tribe of Benjamin, along with Ziba, the servant of Saul's household, and his 15 sons and 20 servants. They rushed to the Jordan ahead of the king.

verses.kjv: And there went over a ferry boat to carry over the king’s household, and to do what he thought good. And Shimei the son of Gera fell down before the king, as he was come over Jordan;
verses.ct: They crossed at the ford to bring the king's household over and to do whatever he needed. As the king was about to cross the Jordan, Shimei son of Gera fell face down in front of him.

verses.kjv: And said unto the king, Let not my lord impute iniquity unto me, neither do thou remember that which thy servant did perversely the day that my lord the king went out of Jerusalem, that the king should take it to his heart.
verses.ct: He said to the king, "Please don't hold my guilt against me, my lord. Don't remember the terrible thing your servant did on the day my lord the king left Jerusalem. Please don't take it to heart.

verses.kjv: For thy servant doth know that I have sinned: therefore, behold, I am come the first this day of all the house of Joseph to go down to meet my lord the king.
verses.ct: Your servant knows that I sinned. That's why I've come today as the first person from the entire house of Joseph to come down and meet my lord the king."

verses.kjv: But Abishai the son of Zeruiah answered and said, Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the LORD’s anointed?
verses.ct: But Abishai son of Zeruiah spoke up and said, "Shouldn't Shimei be executed for this? He cursed the LORD's anointed king!"

verses.kjv: And David said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah, that ye should this day be adversaries unto me? shall there any man be put to death this day in Israel? for do not I know that I am this day king over Israel?
verses.ct: David replied, "What business is this of yours, sons of Zeruiah? Why are you acting as my opponents today? Should anyone be executed in Israel today? Don't I know that today I am once again king over Israel?"

verses.kjv: Therefore the king said unto Shimei, Thou shalt not die. And the king sware unto him.
verses.ct: Then the king said to Shimei, "You will not die." And the king gave him his oath.

verses.kjv: And Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king, and had neither dressed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes, from the day the king departed until the day he came again in peace.
verses.ct: Mephibosheth, Saul's grandson, also came down to meet the king. He had not cared for his feet, trimmed his mustache, or washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he returned safely.

verses.kjv: And it came to pass, when he was come to Jerusalem to meet the king, that the king said unto him, Wherefore wentest not thou with me, Mephibosheth?
verses.ct: When he arrived from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, "Why didn't you come with me, Mephibosheth?"

verses.kjv: And he answered, My lord, O king, my servant deceived me: for thy servant said, I will saddle me an ass, that I may ride thereon, and go to the king; because thy servant is lame.
verses.ct: He answered, "My lord the king, my servant Ziba tricked me. I told him, 'Saddle a donkey for me so I can ride it and go with the king,' because your servant is crippled.

verses.kjv: And he hath slandered thy servant unto my lord the king; but my lord the king is as an angel of God: do therefore what is good in thine eyes.
verses.ct: Ziba has told lies about your servant to my lord the king. But my lord the king is like an angel of God — so do whatever you think is right.

verses.kjv: For all of my father’s house were but dead men before my lord the king: yet didst thou set thy servant among them that did eat at thine own table. What right therefore have I yet to cry any more unto the king?
verses.ct: My entire father's family deserved nothing but death from my lord the king, yet you gave your servant a place among those who eat at your own table. So what right do I have to make any further appeal to the king?"

verses.kjv: And the king said unto him, Why speakest thou any more of thy matters? I have said, Thou and Ziba divide the land.
verses.ct: The king said to him, "Why keep going on about this? I've decided — you and Ziba will split the land."

verses.kjv: And Mephibosheth said unto the king, Yea, let him take all, forasmuch as my lord the king is come again in peace unto his own house.
verses.ct: Mephibosheth said to the king, "Let him take it all! What matters to me is that my lord the king has returned safely to his own home."

verses.kjv: And Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim, and went over Jordan with the king, to conduct him over Jordan.
verses.ct: Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim and crossed the Jordan with the king to escort him across.

verses.kjv: Now Barzillai was a very aged man, even fourscore years old: and he had provided the king of sustenance while he lay at Mahanaim; for he was a very great man.
verses.ct: Barzillai was very old — 80 years old. He had provided for the king during his stay at Mahanaim, because he was a very wealthy man.

verses.kjv: And the king said unto Barzillai, Come thou over with me, and I will feed thee with me in Jerusalem.
verses.ct: The king said to Barzillai, "Cross over with me and stay with me in Jerusalem. I'll take care of you there."

verses.kjv: And Barzillai said unto the king, How long have I to live, that I should go up with the king unto Jerusalem?
verses.ct: But Barzillai replied, "How many years do I have left that I should go to Jerusalem with the king?

verses.kjv: I am this day fourscore years old: and can I discern between good and evil? can thy servant taste what I eat or what I drink? can I hear any more the voice of singing men and singing women? wherefore then should thy servant be yet a burden unto my lord the king?
verses.ct: I'm 80 years old today. Can I still tell the difference between what's enjoyable and what isn't? Can your servant even taste food or drink anymore? Can I still appreciate the sound of singers? Why should your servant be a burden to my lord the king?

verses.kjv: Thy servant will go a little way over Jordan with the king: and why should the king recompense it me with such a reward?
verses.ct: Your servant will cross the Jordan a short distance with the king, but why should the king give me such a generous reward?

verses.kjv: Let thy servant, I pray thee, turn back again, that I may die in mine own city, and be buried by the grave of my father and of my mother. But behold thy servant Chimham; let him go over with my lord the king; and do to him what shall seem good unto thee.
verses.ct: Please let your servant go back so I can die in my own town, near the tomb of my father and mother. But here is your servant Chimham — let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him whatever you think is best."

verses.kjv: And the king answered, Chimham shall go over with me, and I will do to him that which shall seem good unto thee: and whatsoever thou shalt require of me, that will I do for thee.
verses.ct: The king answered, "Chimham will cross over with me, and I'll do for him whatever you think is best. And anything you ask of me, I'll do for you."

verses.kjv: And all the people went over Jordan. And when the king was come over, the king kissed Barzillai, and blessed him; and he returned unto his own place.
verses.ct: So all the people crossed the Jordan, and when the king had crossed over, he kissed Barzillai and blessed him. Then Barzillai returned to his home.

verses.kjv: Then the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him: and all the people of Judah conducted the king, and also half the people of Israel.
verses.ct: The king continued on to Gilgal, and Chimham went with him. All the people of Judah escorted the king, along with half the people of Israel.

verses.kjv: And, behold, all the men of Israel came to the king, and said unto the king, Why have our brethren the men of Judah stolen thee away, and have brought the king, and his household, and all David’s men with him, over Jordan?
verses.ct: Then all the men of Israel came to the king and demanded, "Why did our brothers, the men of Judah, sneak you away and bring the king and his household and all of David's men across the Jordan?"

verses.kjv: And all the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, Because the king is near of kin to us: wherefore then be ye angry for this matter? have we eaten at all of the king’s cost? or hath he given us any gift?
verses.ct: All the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, "Because the king is closely related to us. Why are you upset about this? Have we eaten at the king's expense? Has he given us any special gifts?"

verses.kjv: And the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, and said, We have ten parts in the king, and we have also more right in David than ye: why then did ye despise us, that our advice should not be first had in bringing back our king? And the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the words of the men of Israel.
verses.ct: The men of Israel responded to the men of Judah, "We have 10 shares in the king, and our claim on David is greater than yours. So why did you treat us with contempt? Weren't we the first to talk about bringing our king back?" But the men of Judah spoke even more harshly than the men of Israel.
